author: mengwong
content: greetings fellow humans! I am a functional programmer and language designer developing specification languages to represent laws and (non-smart) contracts, now considering transpilation to Solidity through refinement & extraction methods. One approach we are considering is to reduce the amount of rope that developers seem to be currently using to hang themselves, by creating a higher-level DSL that restricts expressivity to what is both idiomatic and verifiable. I know there has been some work done in formal verification for crypto; I am now looking into the history of languages that target Solidity, similar to how many web dev languages target JS coming from a much terser syntax, or from a different paradigm,  e.g. Elm, Coffeescript.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would love to see a *Design by Contract* language that compiles to Yul or EVM bytecode.

author: sky.cactus
content: Such languages make formal verification a whole lot easier, and allow the author to express their intentions much more clearly than other languages.

author: mengwong
content: I suppose we _could_ generate bytecode directly, but i know there are a handful of verifiers for Solidity which I expect would be valuable as backends, as they do some of the heavy lifting.

author: mengwong
content: What would a very-high-level representation of intent look like? For, say, three of the most common genres.

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> I'm not sure how much work there has been on languages that compile directly to solidity

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> I know there is a project that has been working on a Coq -> Solidity extraction pipeline, I don't have links to hand right now

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> There is a very nice overview of the fv ecosystem for smart contracts here: https://github.com/leonardoalt/ethereum_formal_verification_overviewd

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> In general the biggest / most polished tooling right now is Certora, they have a specification language and can verify properties in this language directly against bytecode. It's used by a lot (even most?) of the major projects on Ethereum atm.

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> I think most of the solidity level verifiers only support outdated solidity versions (except solcmc, which is built directly into the solc compiler). How are you planning to make use of the solidity level verifiers in your extraction pipeline?

author: bridge-bot
content: <xvwx:matrix.dapp.org.uk> Or no I was mistaken. The project I had in mind has extract pipelines from Coq to [liquity](https://liquidity-lang.org/doc/index.html). Still this might be interesting for you: https://github.com/AU-COBRA/ConCert

author: mengwong
content: hey, thanks for all that, that's very helpful. I'll look through all that together with my team and see how we can contribute.
